channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Honduras Election Results Challenged
item.description: Xiomara Castro, the left-wing presidential candidate in last week’s elections, has rejected the official results and called on her supporters to march in the streets.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS PHILLIPS and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Ukrainians Back in Street To Support E.U. Accord
item.description: After the police violently dispersed a protest in Kiev, thousands took to the streets to denounce President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s refusal to sign accords with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Riot police beat back several hundred protesters on Independence Square in Kiev early Saturday.

item.title: The Lede: For Egypt’s New Rulers, Familiar Scapegoats
item.description: The arrest of an Egyptian activist whose blogging has made him the target of four successive governments seemed to signal that the security forces are intent on quashing dissent.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Where Factory Apprenticeship Is Latest Model From Germany
item.description: Labor experts and government officials say that traditional apprenticeship programs, popular in Europe, could help sustain burgeoning growth in American factories.
item.dc:creator: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ
item.media:credit: John W. Adkisson for The New York Times
item.media:description: BMW’s plant in Greer, S.C., is its only one in the United States. The company offers a program called BMW Scholars that allows young workers to study at technical colleges and work.

item.title: Indian Editor Is Arrested in Assault of Employee
item.description: A crusading editor revered in India’s liberal circles, Tarun Tejpal, has been arrested in connection with the sexual assault of a young employee at his magazine.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Afghans Assail Karzai’s Disparate Views on Killings
item.description: Many Afghans have begun to criticize their president for the disparities in his reactions to events and perhaps looking for ways to besmirch the Americans.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The body of a would-be suicide bomber who never reached his target in Kandahar, Afghanistan.

item.title: Japan Takes Airspace Issue to U.N. Agency
item.description: Japan has asked the International Civil Aviation Organization to look into whether China’s new air defense zone in the East China Sea could threaten airline flights in the area.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: North Korea Releases a Video of a U.S. Veteran Confessing to ‘Hostile Acts’
item.description: The veteran, Merrill Newman, 85, who has been held since Oct. 26, read excerpts from the apology from several sheets of white paper.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Korean Central News Agency on Saturday, 85-year-old Merrill Newman reads what the agency said is a written apology for his actions during the Korean War.

item.title: Unraveling Huge Thefts From Girolamini Library in Naples
item.description: Marino Massimo De Caro, the former director of the Girolamini Library in Naples, is accused of stealing thousands of rare books from the historic institution.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Marino Massimo De Caro in 2011. He is now on trial.

item.title: Police Helicopter Crashes Into Crowded Glasgow Pub
item.description: Police officials said eight people were killed in the crash at the pub, the Clutha, where a ska band was performing about 10:30 p.m. Friday when the helicopter spun down onto the building.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Tarps covered the pub in Glasgow on Saturday after at least eight people were killed in the crash Friday.

item.title: Mozambique Airlines Plane Crashes in Namibia, Killing 34
item.description: A Mozambique Airlines plane en route to Angola crashed in a game park in northeast Namibia killing all 34 people on board, a Namibian police official said on Saturday.
item.category: Embraer - Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA|ERJ|NYSE
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 32 to Hospital After Glasgow Helicopter Crash
item.description: The Scottish police say 32 people have been taken to hospitals across Glasgow after a police helicopter crashed into a crowded pub overnight.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Namibia Searches for Missing Plane From Mozambique
item.description: A police helicopter has joined officers on the ground searching on Saturday for a Mozambique Airlines plane carrying 34 people that was reported missing in a remote border area of Namibia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Part II: Adam Minter on China’s Scrap Trade and the Environment
item.description: The journalist Adam Minter examined how China became the world’s largest importer of scrap metal and describes how this has environmental benefits.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: A worker walks past piles of crushed plastic bottles at a recycling factory in Beijing.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: Copter Crashes Into Pub
item.description: A police helicopter slammed into the roof of a popular pub in Glasgow on Friday night, and Scotland’s first minister said a full rescue operation was underway.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Forced Adoption, a Lifetime Quest and a Longing That Never Waned
item.description: In a home for unwed mothers in 1950s Ireland, Philomena Lee’s son was forcibly removed from her. Now, as Judi Dench portrays her in the film version of her story, Ms. Lee speaks of her search and its lessons.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “What we had done was seen as so shameful. Society did not want to know you.”

item.title: North Korea Accuses Captive U.S. Veteran of War Crimes
item.description: The country’s official news agency says Merrill E. Newman, 85, who was detained in October while visiting as a tourist, has acknowledged killing civilians during the Korean War.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Police Helicopter Crashes Into Pub Roof in Scotland
item.description: A police helicopter crashed into the roof of a crowded Glasgow pub, causing "numerous" casualties and leaving people trapped in the unstable building, officials said early Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Airlines Urged by U.S. to Give Notice to China
item.description: The Obama administration is urging American commercial airlines to comply with China’s new air defense zone, hours after China scrambled jets to patrol it.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Nuclear Deal’s Measures May Begin by January, Envoy Says
item.description: Iran agreed to stop uranium enrichment to a fissile concentration of 20 percent and to cap other parts of its nuclear activity in exchange for a limited easing of sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Short on Space, Taiwan Embraces a Boom in Recycling
item.description: In a country that produces more electronics per capita than any other, commercial and government efforts have helped clean up the waste byproducts.
item.dc:creator: By CAIN NUNNS
item.media:credit: Sean Marc Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plant for recycling under construction west of Taipei. Recycling rates in Taiwan are among the highest in the world.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Construction Seen at Rocket Site, Institute Reports
item.description: Commercial satellite imagery shows work has resumed after a hiatus of many months at Tonghae, on the North’s northeast coast, on what looks like a rocket assembly building and a launching control center.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Fire Destroys Factory
item.description: Factory workers angered by rumors that a colleague had been killed by the police set fire to one of Bangladesh’s largest garment factories, destroying the nine-story building, a company official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Mideast Tensions Alarm U.N. Chief
item.description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, expressed alarm about what he called the “increasingly dangerous situation on the ground” in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Chemical Weapons Watchdog Rejects a Request by Syria to Convert Arms Sites
item.description: The group turned down a proposal for 12 of the facilities to be used for storage.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
